text:
The **economy of Ethiopia** is a mixed and transition economy with a large
public sector. The government of Ethiopia is in the process of privatizing
many of the state-owned businesses and moving toward a market economy. The
banking, telecommunication and transportation sectors of the economy are
dominated by government-owned companies.

Ethiopia has one of the fastest-growing economies in the world and is Africa's
second most populous country. Many properties owned by the government during
the previous regime have now been privatized or are in the process of
privatization and the liberalization of its financial sector in the near
future. However, certain sectors such as telecommunications, financial and
insurance services, air and land transportation services, and retail, are
considered to be strategic sectors and are expected to remain under state
control for the foreseeable future.

Almost 50% of Ethiopia's population is under the age of 18. Even though
education enrollment at primary and tertiary level has increased
significantly, job creation has not caught up with the increased number of
secondary and postsecondary educational graduates. The country must create
hundreds of thousands of jobs every year just to keep up with population
growth.

In 2023, Ethiopia reached an estimated GDP of 156.1 billion nominal dollars
and an estimated PPP of 393.85 billion dollars. This mostly comes from a
services-based economy with agriculture. In the latest data from 2019
Ethiopia's top trading partners globally included China, the United States,
UAE, France, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Germany, Japan,
Switzerland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Turkey, India, and Egypt. In 2021,
agriculture made up 37.5% of the country's economic output, while services
36.25% and industry made up 21.85% of the economy. Ethiopia's economy is
ranked 159th place out of 190 countries in 'Ease of doing business'. Ethiopia
is also a part of African Continental Free Trade Area, Common Market for
Eastern and Southern Africa, Intergovernmental Authority on Development, and
the G24, and has observer status at the World Trade Organization. Ethiopia
joined the BRICS economic alliance in January 2024.

While Ethiopia does not currently have a stock exchange, it did have one in
the past during the reign of Emperor Haile Selassie I, called an 'ākisīyoni
gebeya.' It now has a commodity exchange in Addis Ababa called the Ethiopia
Commodity Exchange, established in 2008.

The Ethiopian economy has a large foreign debt, with an overall external debt
of 28 billion US dollars. China owns over 13 billion dollars of its debt. Its
debt to GDP ratio is smaller than similar and neighboring countries. Ethiopia
currently has 2.4 billion dollars of foreign reserves, representing a decline
compared to previous years.

Ethiopia expects to reach a national middle-income status by 2025. Despite
this, based on the most recent data from 2019, 68.7% of the population
continues to be affected by multidimensional poverty and an additional 18.4%
vulnerable to it.
openai_summarised_points: • The economy of Ethiopia is characterized as a mixed and transition economy with a significant public sector presence.
• The Ethiopian government is actively engaged in privatizing many state-owned enterprises and shifting towards a market-oriented economy.
• Key sectors such as banking, telecommunication, and transportation are predominantly controlled by government-owned companies.
• Ethiopia boasts one of the fastest-growing economies globally and is the second most populous country in Africa.
• Many properties previously owned by the government have been privatized or are undergoing privatization, alongside ongoing liberalization of the financial sector.

• Certain strategic sectors—including telecommunications, financial and insurance services, air and land transportation, and retail—are expected to remain under state control for the foreseeable future.
• Approximately 50% of Ethiopia’s population is under the age of 18, indicating a youthful demographic profile.
• Despite significant increases in primary and tertiary education enrollment, job creation has not kept pace with the rising number of secondary and post-secondary graduates.
• Ethiopia must generate hundreds of thousands of new jobs annually to match its population growth.
• In 2023, Ethiopia’s nominal Gross Domestic Product (GDP) was estimated at 156.1 billion US dollars, with a Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) valuation of approximately 393.85 billion dollars.
• The economy is predominantly service-oriented, with agriculture also playing a crucial role.

• As of 2019, Ethiopia’s main trading partners included China, the United States, UAE, France, the United Kingdom, South Korea, Saudi Arabia, Germany, Japan, Switzerland, the Netherlands, Belgium, Turkey, India, and Egypt.
• In 2021, agriculture contributed 37.5% to Ethiopia’s economic output, services accounted for 36.25%, and industry made up 21.85%.
• Ethiopia ranks 159th out of 190 countries in the 'Ease of doing business' index.

• The country is a member of several regional and international trade organizations, including the African Continental Free Trade Area, Common Market for Eastern and Southern Africa, Intergovernmental Authority on Development, and G24; it also holds observer status at the World Trade Organization.
• Ethiopia joined the BRICS economic alliance in January 2024.
• Historically, Ethiopia had a stock exchange during Emperor Haile Selassie I’s reign called an 'ākisīyoni gebeya,' but currently, it does not have an active stock exchange.
• The country operates the Ethiopia Commodity Exchange, established in 2008, located in Addis Ababa.
• Ethiopia has a substantial external debt totaling approximately 28 billion US dollars, with over 13 billion dollars owed to China.
• The country's debt-to-GDP ratio is lower than that of similar and neighboring nations.
• Ethiopia’s foreign exchange reserves stand at about 2.4 billion US dollars, reflecting a decline compared to previous years.
• The government aims for Ethiopia to attain middle-income status by 2025.
• Despite economic growth, as of 2019, 68.7% of the population was affected by multidimensional poverty, with an additional 18.4% vulnerable to it.

text:
Development of GDP per capita

Ethiopia's resources have enabled the country—unlike most sub-Saharan African
countries—to maintain contacts with the outside world for centuries. Since
ancient times, Ethiopian traders exchanged gold, ivory, musk, and wild animal
skins for salt and luxury goods, such as silk and velvet. By the late
nineteenth century, coffee had become one of Ethiopia's more important cash
crops. At that time, most trade flowed along two major trade routes, both of
which terminated in the far southwest in the Kefa-Jima region. From there, one
route went north to Mitsiwa via Gonder and Adwa, the other along the Awash
River valley to Harer and then on to Berbera or Zeila on the Red Sea.

Ethiopia lost its status as a great trading state after the fall of Axum. Most
Ethiopians came to despise traders, preferring instead to emulate the
country's legendary warriors and priests. After establishing a foothold in the
country, Greek, Armenian, and Arab traders became the economic intermediaries
between Ethiopia and the outside world. Arabs also settled in the interior and
eventually dominated all commercial activity except petty trade.

When their occupation of Ethiopia ended in 1941, the Italians left behind them
a country whose economic structure was much as it had been for centuries.
There had been some improvements in communications, particularly in the area
of road building, and attempts had been made to establish a few small
industries and to introduce commercial farming, particularly in Eritrea, which
Italy had occupied since 1890. But these changes were limited. With only a
small proportion of the population participating in the monetized economy,
trade consisted mostly of barter. Wage labor was limited, economic units were
largely self-sufficient, foreign trade was negligible, and the market for
manufactured goods was extremely small.

During the late 1940s and 1950s, much of the economy remained unchanged. The
government focused its development efforts on expansion of the bureaucratic
structure and ancillary services. Most farmers cultivated small plots of land
or herded cattle. Traditional and primitive farming methods provided the
population with a subsistence standard of living. In addition, many nomadic
peoples raised livestock and moved seasonally in drier areas. The agricultural
sector grew slightly, and the industrial sector represented a small part of
the total economy.

By the early 1950s, Emperor Haile Selassie I (reigned 1930–74) had renewed
calls for a transition from a subsistence economy to an agro-industrial
economy. To accomplish this task, Ethiopia needed infrastructure to develop
resources, a material base to improve living conditions, and better health,
education, communications, and other services. A key element of the emperor's
new economic policy was the adoption of centrally administered development
plans.

The First Five-Year Plan (1957–1961) sought to develop strong infrastructure,
particularly in transportation, construction, and communications, to link
isolated regions. The Second Five-Year Plan (1962–1967) signaled the start of
a 20-year program to change Ethiopia's predominantly agricultural economy to
an agro-industrial one. The Third Five-Year Plan (1968–1973) also sought to
facilitate Ethiopia's economic well-being by raising manufacturing and agro-
industrial performance. However, unlike its predecessors, the third plan
expressed the government's willingness to expand educational opportunities and
to improve peasant agriculture.

During the First Five-Year Plan, the gross national product (GNP) increased at
a 3.2 percent annual rate as opposed to the projected figure of 3.7 percent,
and growth in economic sectors such as agriculture, manufacturing, and mining
failed to meet the national plan's targets. The Planning Commission never
assessed the performance of the Second Five-Year Plan and Third Five-Year
Plan, largely because of a shortage of qualified personnel. However, according
to data from the Ethiopian government's Central Statistical Authority, during
the 1960/61 to 1973/74 period the economy achieved sustained economic growth.
Between 1960 and 1970, Ethiopia enjoyed an annual 4.4 percent average growth
rate in per capita gross domestic product (GDP). Relative to its neighbors,
Ethiopia's economic performance was mixed.

By the early 1970s, Ethiopia's economy not only had started to grow but also
had begun to diversify into areas such as manufacturing and services. However,
these changes failed to improve the lives of most Ethiopians. About four-
fifths of the population were subsistence farmers who lived in poverty because
they used most of their meager production to pay taxes, rents, debt payments,
and bribes.

The 1974 revolution resulted in the nationalization and restructuring of the
Ethiopian economy. After the revolution, the country's economy can be viewed
as having gone through four phases. Internal political upheaval, armed
conflict, and radical institutional reform marked the 1974-78 period of the
revolution. There was little economic growth; instead, the government's
nationalization measures and the highly unstable political climate caused
economic dislocation in sectors such as agriculture and manufacturing. As a
result of these problems, GDP increased at an average annual rate of only 0.4
percent.

In the second phase (1978–1980), the economy began to recover as the
government consolidated power and implemented institutional reforms. More
important, security conditions improved as internal and external threats
subsided. GDP grew at an average annual rate of 5.7 percent.

In the third phase (1980–1985), the economy experienced a setback. Except for
Ethiopian fiscal year (EFY) 1982/83, the growth of GDP declined. Manufacturing
took a downturn as well, and agriculture reached a crisis stage, particularly
due to drought that lead to widespread famine.

In the fourth period (1985–1990), the economy continued to stagnate. GDP and
the manufacturing sector also grew during this period, GDP increasing at an
average annual rate of 5 percent. However, the lingering effects of the
1984-85 drought undercut these achievements and contributed to the economy's
overall stag.

Since 1991, the Ethiopian government has embarked on a program of economic
reform, including privatization of state enterprises and rationalization of
government regulation. While the process is still ongoing, the reforms have
attracted foreign direct investment.

In 2015, Ethiopia has 2,700 millionaires, a number that has more than doubled
since 2007. Their fortunes are mainly built-in niches of economic rents
(banks, mines, etc.) without investing in structural and strategic sectors
(industrial production, infrastructure, etc.) and should in no way promote
economic development or represent a source of competition for Western
multinationals.

The Ethiopian government is stepping up its efforts to attract foreign
investors, particularly in the textile sector. They can now import their
machines without customs duties, benefit from a tax exemption for ten years,
pay rents much lower than market prices, and use very inexpensive water and
electricity. Major brands have established themselves in the country, such as
Decathlon, H&M, and Huajian. These companies also benefit from a cheap labor
force, with a monthly salary of around 35 euros. Finally, trade agreements
between Ethiopia and the European Union allow them to export duty-free.
openai_summarised_points: • Ethiopia's resources have historically enabled the country to maintain long-standing contacts with the outside world, unlike most sub-Saharan African nations.
• Since ancient times, Ethiopian traders exchanged gold, ivory, musk, and wild animal skins for salt and luxury goods such as silk and velvet.
• By the late nineteenth century, coffee had become one of Ethiopia's significant cash crops.

• During this period, most trade was conducted along two major routes terminating in the Kefa-Jima region in the southwest: one route went north to Mitsiwa via Gonder and Adwa, and the other along the Awash River valley to Harer, then to Berbera or Zeila on the Red Sea.
• Ethiopia lost its status as a great trading empire after the fall of Axum.
• Post-Axum, Ethiopians increasingly despised traders, preferring to emulate legendary warriors and priests.

• Greek, Armenian, and Arab traders established a foothold in Ethiopia, becoming the primary economic intermediaries between Ethiopia and the outside world; Arabs settled internally and dominated all commercial activity except petty trade.

• Italian occupation ended in 1941, leaving Ethiopia's economic structure largely unchanged from centuries prior, with limited improvements in communications, some small industries, and commercial farming, especially in Eritrea (occupied since 1890).

• The economy was predominantly barter-based with only a small proportion of the population participating in the monetized economy; trade was negligible, wage labor limited, and markets for manufactured goods very small.
• During the late 1940s and 1950s, Ethiopia's economy remained largely unchanged; government efforts focused on expanding bureaucracy and ancillary services.
• Most farmers practiced small-scale cultivation or cattle herding, using traditional methods that provided subsistence living; nomadic peoples raised livestock and moved seasonally in arid regions.
• The agricultural sector experienced slight growth; the industrial sector was minimal.

• By the early 1950s, Emperor Haile Selassie I (reigned 1930–1974) promoted a transition from subsistence to an agro-industrial economy, emphasizing infrastructure development, resource utilization, improved living conditions, health, education, and communication services.
• A key element of Emperor Selassie's economic policy was the adoption of centrally planned development programs.

• The First Five-Year Plan (1957–1961) aimed to develop infrastructure—transportation, construction, and communications—to connect isolated regions; it achieved a 3.2% annual GNP growth, slightly below the projected 3.7%, with sectors like agriculture, manufacturing, and mining failing to meet targets.

• The Second Five-Year Plan (1962–1967) initiated a 20-year program to transform Ethiopia's economy into an agro-industrial one; the Planning Commission did not assess its performance due to personnel shortages.
• The Third Five-Year Plan (1968–1973) aimed to enhance manufacturing and agro-industrial performance, while also expanding educational opportunities and improving peasant agriculture.
• From 1960/61 to 1973/74, Ethiopia experienced sustained economic growth, with an average annual per capita GDP growth rate of 4.4% between 1960 and 1970.
• Relative to neighboring countries, Ethiopia's economic performance was mixed during this period.

• By the early 1970s, Ethiopia's economy had begun diversifying into manufacturing and services, but most of the population remained impoverished subsistence farmers, using their production mainly to pay taxes, rents, debts, and bribes.
• The 1974 revolution led to the nationalization and restructuring of Ethiopia's economy.

• The revolutionary period (1974–1978) was marked by political upheaval, armed conflict, and radical institutional reforms, resulting in minimal economic growth; GDP grew at an average annual rate of only 0.4%.
• During 1978–1980, the economy began recovering as the government consolidated power and implemented reforms, with GDP growth averaging 5.7% annually.
• The period 1980–1985 saw a setback; GDP growth declined except in 1982/83, manufacturing contracted, and agriculture faced a crisis due to drought and famine.
• From 1985–1990, the economy stagnated with GDP growth averaging 5% annually; drought effects from 1984–85 hampered overall economic progress.
• Since 1991, Ethiopia has implemented economic reforms including privatization of state enterprises and deregulation, which have attracted foreign direct investment.

• As of 2015, Ethiopia had 2,700 millionaires, more than doubling since 2007; their wealth is primarily derived from economic rents in sectors like banking and mining, not from investments in strategic or industrial sectors.

• The Ethiopian government is actively promoting foreign investment, especially in textiles, offering incentives such as duty-free import of machines, ten-year tax exemptions, low rent prices, and inexpensive water and electricity.
• Major international brands such as Decathlon, H&M, and Huajian have established operations in Ethiopia, benefiting from cheap labor with monthly wages around 35 euros.
• Trade agreements between Ethiopia and the European Union enable duty-free exports for Ethiopian products.

As of 2023[update], agriculture accounts for almost 36% of GDP, 81 percent of
exports, and 73 percent of the labour force. Many other economic activities
depend on agriculture, including marketing, processing, and export of
agricultural products. Production is overwhelmingly of a subsistence nature,
and a large part of commodity exports are provided by the small agricultural
cash-crop sector. Principal crops include coffee, pulses (e.g., beans),
oilseeds, cereals, potatoes, sugarcane, and vegetables. Exports are almost
entirely agricultural commodities, with coffee as the largest foreign exchange
earner, and its flower industry becoming a new source of revenue: for
2005/2006 (the latest year available) Ethiopia's coffee exports represented
0.9% of the world exports, and oilseeds and flowers each representing 0.5%.
Ethiopia is Africa's second biggest maize producer. In 2000, Ethiopia's
livestock contributed to 19% of total GDP.

As of 2008[update], some countries that import most of their food, such as
Saudi Arabia, have begun planning the purchase and development of large tracts
of arable land in developing countries such as Ethiopia. This land grabbing
has raised fears of food being exported to more prosperous countries while the
local population faces its own shortage.

Forest products are mainly logs used in construction. The silvicutural
products are used in construction and manufacturing, and as energy sources.
Ethiopia's fisheries are entirely fresh water, as it has no marine coastline.
Although total production has been continuously increasing since 2007, the
fishing industry is a very small part of the economy. Fishing is predominantly
artisanal. In 2014, nearly 45,000 fishermen were employed in the sector with
only 30% of them employed full-time.

Employees of Ethiopian garment factories, who work for brands such as Guess,
H&M or Calvin Klein, receive a monthly salary of 26 dollars per month. These
very low wages have led to low productivity, frequent strikes and high
turnover. Some factories have replaced all their employees on average every 12
months, according to a 2019 report of the Stern Centre for Business and Human
Rights at New York University.
openai_summarised_points: • Employees of Ethiopian garment factories working for international brands such as Guess, H&M, and Calvin Klein receive a monthly salary of only 26 US dollars.
• The extremely low wages paid to these workers have resulted in low productivity levels within the industry.
• The low wages and working conditions have contributed to frequent strikes among factory employees.
• High employee turnover is a significant issue in the Ethiopian textile industry, with some factories replacing all their employees on average every 12 months.
• These findings are based on a 2019 report from the Stern Centre for Business and Human Rights at New York University.

Microcline from the Kenticha mine, Oromia Region, Ethiopia.

Mining is important to the economy of Ethiopia as a diversification from
agriculture. Currently, mining comprises only 1% of GDP. Gold, gemstones
(diamonds and sapphires), and industrial minerals are important commodities
for the country's export-oriented growth strategy.

The country has deposits of coal, opal, gemstones, kaolin, iron ore, soda ash,
and tantalum, but only gold is mined in significant quantities. In Salt
extraction from salt beds in the Afar Depression, as well as from salt springs
in Dire and Afder districts in the south, is only of internal importance and
only a negligible amount is exported.

Tantalum mining has also been profitable. It was reported that in the late
1980s, the mineral industry lacked importance given that it contributed less
than 0.2 percent of Ethiopia's GDP. Mining for gold is a key development
sector in the country. Gold export, which was just US$5 million in 2001, has
recorded a large increase to US$602 million in 2012. 2001 gold production
amounted to some 3.4 tons.
openai_summarised_points: • Mining is a significant sector in Ethiopia's economy, serving as a diversification from the dominant agricultural industry.
• Currently, the mining sector contributes approximately 1% to Ethiopia's Gross Domestic Product (GDP).
• Key mineral commodities for Ethiopia's export-oriented growth strategy include gold, gemstones (such as diamonds and sapphires), and industrial minerals.
• Ethiopia possesses deposits of various minerals, including coal, opal, gemstones, kaolin, iron ore, soda ash, and tantalum; however, only gold is mined in substantial quantities.

• Salt extraction occurs from salt beds in the Afar Depression and from salt springs in the Dire and Afder districts in the south, but this activity is primarily for internal consumption, with only negligible amounts exported.
• Tantalum mining has proven profitable in Ethiopia; however, in the late 1980s, the mineral industry was relatively insignificant, contributing less than 0.2% to the national GDP.
• Gold mining is considered a key development sector for Ethiopia, with significant growth in gold exports over the years.
• Gold exports increased dramatically from US$5 million in 2001 to US$602 million in 2012.
• Gold production in 2001 was approximately 3.4 tons.

text:
Waterpower and forests are Ethiopia's main energy sources. The country derives
about 90 percent of its electricity needs from hydropower, which means that
electricity generation, as with agriculture, is dependent on abundant
rainfall. Present installed capacity is rated at about 2000 megawatts, with
planned expansion to 10,000 megawatts. In general, Ethiopians rely on forests
for nearly all of their energy and construction needs; the result has been
deforestation of much of the highlands during the last three decades. Ethiopia
has set out plans to invest $40 billion to 71 energy projects by 2030

Ethiopian Prime Minister Ahmed with Indian counterpart Prime Minister Narendra
Modi meeting for Ethiopia's admission to the alliance

Less than one-half of Ethiopia's towns and cities are connected to the
national grid. Petroleum requirements are met via imports of refined products,
although some oil is being hauled overland from Sudan. Oil exploration in
Ethiopia has been underway for decades, ever since Emperor Haile Selassie I
granted a 50-year concession to SOCONY-Vacuum in September 1945.

Recent oil and gas discoveries across East Africa have seen the region emerge
as a new player in the global oil and gas industry. As exciting as the huge
gas fields of East Africa are, however, the strong decline in oil prices and
expectations for an L-shaped recovery with low prices over the coming years
are increasingly challenging the economic viability of the industry in this
region. The reserves are estimated at 4 trillion cubic feet (110×10~~^~~ 9
m3), while exploration for gas and oil is underway in the Gambela Region
bordering South Sudan. The discoveries were expected to drive billions of
dollars in annual investment to the region over the next decade. According to
BMI estimates, the findings in the last few years are more than that of any
other region in the world, and the discoveries are expected to continue for
the next few years. However, falling global oil prices are threatening the
commercial viability of many of these gas prospects.
openai_summarised_points: • Waterpower and forests are Ethiopia's primary energy sources, with hydropower accounting for approximately 90 percent of the country's electricity needs.
• Ethiopia's electricity generation is heavily dependent on abundant rainfall, similar to its agricultural sector.
• The current installed electricity capacity in Ethiopia is about 2,000 megawatts, with plans to expand this capacity to 10,000 megawatts.
• Ethiopians rely on forests for nearly all of their energy and construction needs, leading to significant deforestation of the highlands over the past three decades.
• Ethiopia has outlined plans to invest a total of $40 billion in 71 energy projects by the year 2030.
• Less than 50 percent of Ethiopian towns and cities are connected to the national electricity grid.
• Petroleum needs in Ethiopia are met through imports of refined products, with some oil transported overland from Sudan.
• Oil exploration in Ethiopia has been ongoing for decades, beginning with Emperor Haile Selassie I granting a 50-year concession to SOCONY-Vacuum in September 1945.
• Recent oil and gas discoveries across East Africa have positioned the region as a new player in the global oil and gas industry.

• Despite the large gas fields in East Africa, declining oil prices and expectations of an L-shaped economic recovery with sustained low prices pose challenges to the industry's economic viability in the region.
• Ethiopia's oil and gas reserves are estimated at 4 trillion cubic feet (approximately 110 billion cubic meters).
• Exploration for gas and oil is currently underway in the Gambela Region, bordering South Sudan.
• The recent discoveries in Ethiopia are expected to attract billions of dollars in annual investment over the next decade.
• According to BMI estimates, Ethiopia's recent oil and gas findings surpass those of any other region globally, with exploration expected to continue for several more years.
• Falling global oil prices threaten the commercial viability of many of Ethiopia's gas prospects and regional oil projects.

text:
Prior to the outbreak of the 1998–2000 Eritrean–Ethiopian War, landlocked
Ethiopia mainly relied on the seaports of Asseb and Massawa in Eritrea for
international trade.

As of 2005[update], Ethiopia uses the ports of Djibouti, connected to Addis
Ababa by the Addis Ababa – Djibouti Railway, and to a lesser extent Port Sudan
in Sudan. In May 2005, the Ethiopian government began negotiations to use the
port of Berbera in Somaliland.

By 2030, the government expects a $74 billion investment in transportation.
openai_summarised_points: • Prior to the outbreak of the 1998–2000 Eritrean–Ethiopian War, Ethiopia, being landlocked, primarily relied on the seaports of Asseb and Massawa in Eritrea for its international trade activities.
• As of 2005, Ethiopia's main ports of use include the port of Djibouti, which is connected to Addis Ababa via the Addis Ababa – Djibouti Railway, facilitating freight and passenger movement.
• In addition to Djibouti, Ethiopia also utilized the port of Port Sudan in Sudan to a lesser extent for its maritime trade needs.
• In May 2005, the Ethiopian government initiated negotiations to gain access to the port of Berbera in Somaliland, aiming to diversify and enhance its port access options.
• The Ethiopian government has set a target to invest approximately $74 billion in transportation infrastructure by the year 2030, reflecting a significant long-term development plan for the sector.

text:
The services sector consists almost entirely of tourism, with additional
economic opportunity in wholesale and retail trade, transportation, and
communications. Developed in the 1960s, tourism declined greatly during the
late 1970s and the 1980s under the military government. Recovery began in the
1990s, but growth has been constrained by the lack of suitable hotels and
other infrastructure, the impact of drought, the 1998–2000 war with Eritrea,
and the specter of terrorism. In 2002 more than 156,000 tourists entered the
country, many of them Ethiopians visiting from abroad, spending more than
US$77 million. In 2008, the number of tourists entering the country had
increased to 330,000. A decade later, in 2019, Ethiopia registered a record of
812,000 tourists visiting the country, bringing a revenue of $3.55 bn (4.2
percent of the gross national product).
openai_summarised_points: • The services sector in Ethiopia is predominantly composed of tourism, with additional contributions from wholesale and retail trade, transportation, and communications.
• Tourism development in Ethiopia began in the 1960s but experienced a significant decline during the late 1970s and the 1980s under the military government.

• The tourism industry in Ethiopia started to recover in the 1990s; however, growth has been limited by several factors including the lack of suitable hotels and infrastructure, the impact of drought, the 1998–2000 war with Eritrea, and concerns over terrorism.
• In 2002, Ethiopia received over 156,000 tourists, many of whom were Ethiopians visiting from abroad, with total tourist expenditure exceeding US$77 million.
• By 2008, the number of tourists entering Ethiopia increased to approximately 330,000.
• In 2019, Ethiopia recorded a peak of 812,000 tourists visiting the country, generating a tourism revenue of $3.55 billion, which accounted for 4.2 percent of the gross national product.

• Ethiopia's share of global GDP based on Purchasing Power Parity (PPP) was 0.08% in 1980, decreased slightly to 0.07% in 1990 and 2000, then increased to 0.10% in 2010, and further rose to 0.16% in 2017, indicating gradual growth in Ethiopia's relative economic size on the world stage.

• According to estimates by the International Monetary Fund (IMF), Ethiopia's gross domestic product (GDP) at market prices in millions of Ethiopian Birr showed a consistent upward trend from 14,665 million Birr in 1980 to 8,499,779 million Birr in 2023.

• In 1980, Ethiopia's GDP was 14,665 million Birr, equivalent to 190 USD per capita, with an exchange rate of 2.06 Birr per USD; by 1990, GDP increased to 25,011 million Birr, with per capita income rising to 257 USD, maintaining the same exchange rate of 2.06 Birr per USD.

• Between 1995 and 2000, Ethiopia's GDP grew from 47,560 million Birr (148 USD per capita) to 64,398 million Birr (124 USD per capita), with the exchange rate changing from 5.88 Birr to 8.15 Birr per USD, reflecting currency devaluation.

• From 2000 onwards, Ethiopia experienced substantial economic growth: GDP increased from 64,398 million Birr (124 USD per capita) in 2000 to 171,834 million Birr (253 USD per capita) in 2007, and further to 245,973 million Birr (333 USD per capita) in 2008, with the exchange rate rising to 9.67 Birr per USD.

• The GDP in 2009 was 386,215 million Birr, with a per capita income of 398 USD, and an exchange rate of 12.39 Birr per USD; in 2010, GDP reached 427,026 million Birr, with per capita income decreasing slightly to 361 USD, and the exchange rate increasing to 13.33 Birr per USD.

• Ethiopia's GDP continued to grow rapidly, reaching 1,832,786 million Birr (823 USD per capita) in 2017, 3,374,349 million Birr (969 USD per capita) in 2020, and 8,499,779 million Birr (1,473 USD per capita) in 2023, demonstrating significant economic expansion.

• The current GDP per capita in USD experienced a 43% decline during the 1990s, indicating a period of economic hardship or stagnation, but since 2004, Ethiopia has maintained continuous real GDP growth of at least 5% annually.

• The main economic indicators from 1980 to 2023 show Ethiopia's GDP in PPP terms increased from 10.5 billion USD in 1980 to 215.1 billion USD in 2017, reaching 393.3 billion USD in 2023, with GDP per capita rising from 324 USD to 2,303 USD in 2017 and 3,719 USD in 2023.
• Ethiopia's nominal GDP grew from 7.4 billion USD in 1980 to 92.6 billion USD in 2019, and further to 155.8 billion USD in 2023, reflecting rapid economic expansion.

• The annual real GDP growth rate was 4.0% in 1980, fluctuated in the following years, reaching a peak of 13.9% in 1987, then declined during the late 1980s and early 1990s, with negative growth in some years such as 1984 (−2.3%) and 1985 (−11.4%).

• From 2004 onward, Ethiopia experienced sustained high growth rates, with GDP growth reaching 11.7% in 2004, 11.8% in 2007, and peaking at 11.2% in 2008, then stabilizing around 6–10% in subsequent years, including 6.1% in 2020 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

• Inflation rates in Ethiopia varied significantly over the years, with periods of high inflation such as 1985 (−11.4%) and 1987 (13.9%), and relatively low inflation below 5% in recent years, notably 4.0% in 1980, 1.0% in 1982, and below 5% from 2018 onward.

• Ethiopia's government debt as a percentage of GDP fluctuated, reaching 75.3% in 1992, decreasing to 68.8% in 1997, then rising again to 120.8% in 1993, and stabilizing around 36.1% in 2023, indicating varying levels of fiscal sustainability.

• Between 2010 and 2023, Ethiopia's economy experienced strong, broad-based growth averaging approximately 9.4% annually from 2010/11 to 2019/20, with a slowdown to 6.1% in 2019/20 due to the COVID-19 pandemic.

• The COVID-19 pandemic impacted Ethiopia's growth, with real GDP growth slowing from over 10% in previous years to 6.1% in 2019/20, primarily driven by growth in industry (notably construction) and services sectors.
• Agriculture in Ethiopia was resilient during the COVID-19 pandemic, with its contribution to overall growth slightly improving in 2019/20 compared to the previous year.
• Demand-side growth was mainly fueled by private consumption and public investment, with public investment assuming an increasingly significant role in driving economic expansion during this period.

text:
Share of population in extreme poverty over time The African country of
Ethiopia has made strides towards alleviating poverty since 2000 when it was
assessed that their poverty rate was one of the greatest among all other
countries. The country has made great strides in different areas of the
Millennium Development Goals including eradicating various diseases and
decreasing the rate of child mortality. Despite these improvements, poverty is
still extremely high within the country. Based on the most recent data from
2019, 68.7% of the population is affected by multidimensional poverty and an
additional 18.4% vulnerable to it. One of the leading factors in driving down
poverty was the expansion of the agricultural sector. Poor farmers have been
able to set higher food prices to increase their sales and revenue, but this
expansion has come at a cost to the poorest citizens of the country, as they
could not afford the higher priced food. One of the biggest challenges to
alleviating this issue is changing the structure of Ethiopia's economy from an
agricultural-based economy to a more industry-based economy. The current
strategy for addressing poverty in Ethiopia is by building on existing
government systems and development programs that are already in place within
the country.
openai_summarised_points: • Since 2000, Ethiopia has made significant progress in reducing poverty, which was previously among the highest in the world.
• The country has achieved notable improvements in various Millennium Development Goals, including the eradication of certain diseases and reductions in child mortality rates.
• Despite these advancements, poverty remains a critical issue in Ethiopia.
• As of 2019, 68.7% of the Ethiopian population is affected by multidimensional poverty, which considers factors beyond income such as health, education, and living standards.
• An additional 18.4% of the population is classified as vulnerable to multidimensional poverty, indicating they are at risk of falling into poverty without intervention.
• A key factor in poverty reduction has been the expansion of Ethiopia’s agricultural sector, which has allowed poor farmers to increase food prices, thereby boosting their sales and revenue.
• However, this agricultural growth has negatively impacted the poorest citizens, as they are unable to afford the higher-priced food resulting from increased agricultural output.
• One of the primary challenges in alleviating poverty is transforming Ethiopia’s economy from being predominantly agricultural-based to a more industrialized economy.
• The current strategy for poverty alleviation involves leveraging existing government systems and development programs already established within Ethiopia.

text:
Ethiopian exports in 2006

Until 2013, the major agricultural export crop was coffee, providing about
26.4% of Ethiopia's foreign exchange earnings. In the beginning of 2014,
oilseeds exports have been more important. Coffee is critical to the Ethiopian
economy. More than 15 million people (25% of the population) derive their
livelihood from the coffee sector. Other exports include live animals, leather
and leather products, chemicals, gold, pulses, oilseeds, flowers, fruits and
vegetables and khat (or _qat_), a leafy shrub which has psychotropic qualities
when chewed. Cross-border trade by pastoralists is often informal and beyond
state control and regulation. In East Africa, over 95% of cross-border trade
is through unofficial channels and the unofficial trade of live cattle,
camels, sheep and goats from Ethiopia sold to Somalia, Kenya and Djibouti
generates an estimated total value of between US$250 and US$300 million
annually (100 times more than the official figure). This trade helps lower
food prices, increase food security, relieve border tensions and promote
regional integration. However, there are also risks as the unregulated and
undocumented nature of this trade runs risks, such as allowing disease to
spread more easily throughout the region. Furthermore, the government of
Ethiopia is purportedly unhappy with lost tax revenue and foreign exchange
revenues. Recent initiatives have sought to document and regulate this trade.

Dependent on a few vulnerable crops for its foreign exchange earnings and
reliant on imported oil, Ethiopia lacks sufficient foreign exchange. The
financially conservative government has taken measures to solve this problem,
including stringent import controls and sharply reduced subsidies on retail
gasoline prices. Nevertheless, the largely subsistence economy is incapable of
supporting high military expenditures, drought relief, an ambitious
development plan, and indispensable imports such as oil; it therefore depends
on foreign assistance.

In December 1999, Ethiopia signed a $1.4 billion joint venture deal with the
Malaysian oil company, Petronas, to develop a huge natural gas field in the
Somali Region. By the year 2010, however, implementation failed to progress
and Petronas lost its license to develop the field, which is now being
invested in by Chinese company, Poly-GCL Petroleum.[_which?_] Ethiopia has
already begun exporting electricity to Kenya, South Sudan and Djibouti.
Earning from this has generated US$300 million annually. After the completion
of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) total generation of exports to
neighboring countries is expected to bring in US$1 billion annually to the
economy.

The dam, which was completed in 2023, is the largest hydroelectric power plant
in Africa as well as among the 20 largest in the world.
openai_summarised_points: • Until 2013, coffee was Ethiopia's major agricultural export crop, accounting for approximately 26.4% of the country's foreign exchange earnings.
• At the beginning of 2014, oilseeds exports became more significant in Ethiopia’s export profile.
• Coffee remains critical to the Ethiopian economy, with over 15 million people, representing about 25% of the population, deriving their livelihoods from the coffee sector.

• Other notable Ethiopian exports include live animals, leather and leather products, chemicals, gold, pulses, oilseeds, flowers, fruits, vegetables, and khat (or _qat_), a leafy shrub with psychotropic effects when chewed.
• Cross-border trade by Ethiopian pastoralists is predominantly informal, often occurring outside state control and regulation.

• In East Africa, over 95% of cross-border trade occurs through unofficial channels, with the unregulated trade of live cattle, camels, sheep, and goats from Ethiopia to Somalia, Kenya, and Djibouti valued at an estimated US$250 to US$300 million annually, which is approximately 100 times the official figures.

• This informal trade helps lower food prices, enhance food security, reduce border tensions, and promote regional integration, but it also poses risks such as facilitating the spread of diseases due to its unregulated nature.

• The Ethiopian government is reportedly dissatisfied with the loss of tax revenue and foreign exchange earnings resulting from unregulated cross-border trade, prompting recent efforts to document and regulate these activities.
• Ethiopia's economy is heavily dependent on a few vulnerable crops for foreign exchange and relies on imported oil, leading to a shortage of foreign currency reserves.
• The government has implemented measures such as strict import controls and significant reductions in subsidies on retail gasoline to address foreign exchange shortages.

• Despite these measures, Ethiopia's largely subsistence economy struggles to support high military expenditures, drought relief, ambitious development projects, and essential imports like oil, necessitating foreign aid.

• In December 1999, Ethiopia signed a $1.4 billion joint venture agreement with Malaysian oil company Petronas to develop a large natural gas field in the Somali Region; however, by 2010, implementation stalled, and Petronas lost its license, with Chinese company Poly-GCL Petroleum now involved in the development.
• Ethiopia has begun exporting electricity to neighboring countries including Kenya, South Sudan, and Djibouti, generating approximately US$300 million annually from these exports.

• The completion of the Grand Ethiopian Renaissance Dam (GERD) in 2023 is expected to significantly boost Ethiopia’s electricity exports, with total annual revenue projected to reach US$1 billion after full operational capacity.
• The GERD is the largest hydroelectric power plant in Africa and ranks among the 20 largest hydroelectric plants worldwide.
